title: Muktzeh: moving money on Shabbat
vignette: Yosef spots coins left on his windowsill right before Shabbat begins. Leaving them might attract thieves. Is he allowed to move the money once Shabbat starts?

options.text: Leave the money despite the risk.
Move the coins to a safe place discreetly.

title: Gentile housekeeper lighting candles
vignette: A Jewish family forgot to light Shabbat candles. Their non-Jewish housekeeper offers to light them after sunset. May they let her?

options.text: Allow the housekeeper to light.
Decline; benefit from such work is forbidden.

title: Visiting the sick carrying medicine
vignette: Leah wishes to bring medicine to her ill friend on Shabbat. Carrying outside is normally prohibited, but the friend may suffer without it.

options.text: Carry the medicine; alleviate the suffering.
Refrain from carrying; wait until after Shabbat.

title: Extinguishing a fire on Shabbat
vignette: A kitchen blaze threatens to spread to neighbouring homes. Can the family put it out to save property?

options.text: Let it burn unless lives are in danger.
Extinguish quickly to protect everyone.

title: Killing a venomous scorpion
vignette: A scorpion crawls toward sleeping children on Shabbat. Killing creatures is normally forbidden.

options.text: Kill it to remove the threat.
Trap it without killing and release later.

title: Wearing loose jewelry outside
vignette: Rivka wants to wear a new pin to synagogue but it might slip off and she would carry it four cubits.

options.text: Wear it and be careful not to drop it.
Avoid wearing it to prevent accidental carrying.

title: Bathing in hot water prepared before Shabbat
vignette: Water was heated legally before Shabbat. May the family take warm baths on Shabbat afternoon?

options.text: Bathe and enjoy the prepared comfort.
Refrain; others might suspect it was heated today.

title: Circumcising a slightly ill newborn
vignette: The eighth day falls on Shabbat but the baby has a mild fever. Should the circumcision proceed?

options.text: Delay until the infant is well.
Perform it now to fulfil the commandment on time.

title: Gentile courier carrying goods
vignette: A non-Jewish messenger arrives on Shabbat willing to deliver your wine across town. Can you let him?

options.text: Allow him to carry on his own initiative.
Refuse; it appears as if he acts for you.

title: Saving holy books from a fire
vignette: A small blaze breaks out near the bookshelf on Shabbat. May sacred scrolls be carried to safety outside?

options.text: Rescue them; their sanctity warrants it.
Leave them; carrying to a public domain is forbidden.

title: Freeing livestock stuck in a pit
vignette: A cow falls into a shallow ditch on Shabbat. Extraction requires constructing a ramp.

options.text: Build it and free the animal to prevent suffering.
Wait until after Shabbat even if the animal suffers.

title: Using medicine for minor pain
vignette: Rachel has a throbbing headache on Shabbat. Taking medicine is generally restricted when not life-threatening.

options.text: Take the pill for relief.
Endure the pain until Shabbat ends.

title: Clapping and dancing at a celebration
vignette: Guests at a Shabbat wedding want to clap and dance joyfully though some sages banned it lest instruments be fixed.

options.text: Join the dancing; rejoice with the couple.
Refrain from rhythmic clapping and dancing.

title: Helping a mother in labor
vignette: A woman begins labor on Shabbat. Extensive work will be required to care for her and the newborn.

options.text: Do everything necessary even if it involves Shabbat violations.
Minimize work and do only what is absolutely required.

title: Moving a heavy object blocking a doorway
vignette: A large barrel rolled in front of the house entrance on Shabbat. Moving it may involve exertion normally avoided.

options.text: Shift it aside to allow people in and out.
Leave it until Shabbat ends.
